tutorials.title: 1. Hello World
tutorials.description: Our first program will print the classic "Hello World" message. This is the entry point of any BPL program.

tutorials.title: 2. Values
tutorials.description: BPL has various value types including strings, integers, floats, and booleans. Strings are pointers to characters (`*u8`). Integers can be signed (`i64`) or unsigned (`u64`). Floats are `f64` or `f32`.

tutorials.title: 3. Variables
tutorials.description: Variables are declared using `local` (or `global`) followed by the name, type, and optional initialization.

tutorials.title: 4. Constants
tutorials.description: BPL supports constants using the `const` keyword. Constants must be initialized and cannot be changed.

tutorials.title: 5. For (Loops)
tutorials.description: BPL has only one looping construct, `loop`, which creates an infinite loop. You can simulate `while` and `for` loops using `break` and `continue`.

tutorials.title: 6. If/Else
tutorials.description: Branching with `if` and `else` is straightforward. Braces `{}` are required.

tutorials.title: 7. Switch
tutorials.description: Switch statements express conditionals across many branches.

tutorials.title: 8. Arrays
tutorials.description: Arrays are fixed-size sequences of elements of a specific type.

tutorials.title: 9. Functions
tutorials.description: Functions are central in BPL. Use `frame` to declare them and `call` to invoke them.

tutorials.title: 10. Recursion
tutorials.description: BPL supports recursive functions.

tutorials.title: 11. Pointers
tutorials.description: BPL supports pointers, allowing you to pass references to values.

tutorials.title: 12. Strings
tutorials.description: Strings are pointers to null-terminated byte arrays (`*u8`).

tutorials.title: 13. Structs
tutorials.description: Structs are typed collections of fields.

tutorials.title: 14. Struct Methods
tutorials.description: Structs can have methods defined inside them using the 'frame' keyword. Use 'this' to access the struct instance.

tutorials.title: 15. Generic Structs
tutorials.description: BPL supports generic structs with type parameters. Methods on generic structs can use the type parameters.

tutorials.title: 16. Errors
tutorials.description: It's idiomatic to return errors as a separate return value (e.g. via a struct) or status code.

tutorials.title: 17. Variadic Functions
tutorials.description: Variadic functions can be called with any number of trailing arguments.

tutorials.title: 18. Sorting
tutorials.description: Implementing a simple sort algorithm.

tutorials.title: 19. Panic
tutorials.description: Use `exit` to immediately terminate the program with an error code.

tutorials.title: 20. String Functions
tutorials.description: Standard library string functions.

tutorials.title: 21. String Formatting
tutorials.description: String formatting via `printf`.

tutorials.title: 22. Time
tutorials.description: Using `time` from libc.

tutorials.title: 23. Random Numbers
tutorials.description: Using `rand` and `srand`.

tutorials.title: 24. Number Parsing
tutorials.description: Parsing numbers from strings using `atoi` and `strtod`.

tutorials.title: 25. Writing Files
tutorials.description: Writing files using C standard library functions.

tutorials.title: 26. Reading Files
tutorials.description: Reading files using C standard library functions.

tutorials.title: 27. Command-Line Arguments
tutorials.description: Accessing command-line arguments via `argc` and `argv`.

tutorials.title: 28. Environment Variables
tutorials.description: Accessing environment variables using `getenv`.

tutorials.title: 29. Spawning Processes
tutorials.description: Running external commands using `system`.

tutorials.title: 30. Exit
tutorials.description: Exiting the program with a status code.
